--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Nat Pryce" <nat.pryce@...> wrote:

> I usual=
ly use mock objects where the real object has a plug-in point
> at which it=
 talks through an interface to another object.  The test
> needs to express=
 how the object calls out through the interface, not
> how the object and o=
ne specific implementation  work.

Seems sound, because that's the definiti=
on of the interface, anyway,
if that's what is used there. An interface mus=
tn't have anything to do
with implementation, at all.

So how and where do =
the tests express how the object calls out through
the interface?
Maybe in =
the mock implementation by doing some assertions on the
arguments of the in=
terface-method? So are you allowed to put part of
your assertions other tha=
n the test method-body in JUnit?

Thanks for sharing your experiences, Nat!=

Csaba
